pages.text: $(l:the_world/ores_and_minerals)Ores$() can be $(l:getting_started/finding_ores)smelted$() and $(l:getting_started/finding_ores)cast$() directly, at first using a $(l:getting_started/pottery#vessel)Small Vessel$() and firing it in a $(l:getting_started/pit_kiln)Pit Kiln$() or in a $(l:mechanics/charcoal_forge)Charcoal Forge$().However, ores can be processed to further increase their yield!

pages.title: Ore Grinding
pages.text: Ore processing starts with a $(l:mechanics/quern)Quern$(). You can turn ores into powders, increasing their yield by 20%! Each powder is worth 6$(thing)mB$().

The next step in the process is the creation of $(thing)Ore Slurry$(). This liquid is composed of the powdered ore in water. After a while in a sealed barrel, the ore powder becomes a liquid. It takes 250mB of water per powder for making 250mB of slurry.

pages.title: Frothing
pages.text: After you have a slurry, take a bucket of it and place it in a pot with an empty pan, and let it boil for a few minutes. This will generate 4 Refined Ore Powders, each worth 8mB each. Don't worry, you'll get your pan back...
Compressing the powder further refines it to increase its yield to 40mB, but is not the final step of the process.

pages.title: Roasting
pages.text: You can further roast the resulting ore, by placing one to five compressed powders in the pot, with a small amount of water (100mB). This will result in a sturdy brick worth 50mB of ore, or almost 2.5 times the amount we started with!
It is possible to split the result into 5 10mB pieces of Roasted Powder, but doing so requires a hammer.
